title: Bookland
synopsis: [[Bookland]] is a good example of how the automatic clustering and then mapping of relationships can have real significance.

title: Changes to this Site
synopsis: Below we list recent changes to this site only without also listing changes from the [[Neighbourhood]]:

title: Context Map
synopsis: An individual [[bounded context]] leaves some problems in the absence of a global view. The context of other models may still be vague and in flux.

title: Currently Working On
synopsis: Here is a list of [[Recent Changes]] I consider important. View our experiments on the [[Scratch]] page. To clear stuff saved in your browser try [[Local Changes]].

title: Embedding GitHub Geojson
synopsis: Want to make your [[geoJSON]] map available someplace other than [[GitHub]]? Simply modify this template, and place it in any HTML page that supports javascript (e.g., [[GitHub Pages]]):

title: Feast Page Template
synopsis: This is the grey subtitle

title: Fedwiki Tools
synopsis: Here we list a few tools that are of particular use in managing and creating [[Fedwiki]] content.

title: Finsbury Park Festival
synopsis: A page with 1 items.

title: Geographic Wiki Map
synopsis: The term map can be confusing. Here we explore geographic maps (not a graph or diagramme) in wiki.

title: GeoJSON
synopsis: GeoJSON is an open standard format designed for representing simple geographical features, along with their non-spatial attributes, based on JavaScript Object Notation - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geojson wikipedia]

title: Import Google Photo
synopsis: Here we look at how we can drag an image from Google Photos into wiki. It uses the Picassa web api which is not listed in the api console - [https://developers.google.com/picasa-web/docs/3.0/developers_guide_protocol#Albums developers.google.com]

title: Leaflet
synopsis: [[LeafletJS]] is a widely used open source JavaScript library used to build web mapping applications. First released in 2011, it supports most mobile and desktop platforms, supporting [[HTML5]] and [[CSS3]].

title: Leafletjs
synopsis: [[Leaflet]] is a widely used open source JavaScript library used to build web mapping applications. First released in 2011, it supports most mobile and desktop platforms, supporting [[HTML5]] and [[CSS3]].

title: Map Me
synopsis: A page with 0 items.

title: Map of Science
synopsis: Science mapping, at its most basic, is a combination of classification and visualization.

title: Map Transport
synopsis: This [[Transport]] creates a fedwiki [[ghost page]] from a geo-located image. It uses [[exiv2]] on the server to extract the GPSInfo in the [[Exif]] headers of the image.

title: Mapbox
synopsis: Mapbox is a large provider of custom online maps for websites such as Foursquare, Pinterest, Evernote, the Financial Times, The Weather Channel and Uber Technologies - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mapbox wikipedia]

title: MapMe API
synopsis: Mapme API is a RESTful builder tool for maps. Mounted as a service on Google Maps API, Mapme facilitates easy creation and customization of content on maps - [http://www.programmableweb.com/api/mapme programmableweb.com]

title: Mapnik
synopsis: Mapnik is an open source mapping toolkit for desktop- and server-based map rendering, written in C++.

title: Mapping a Path
synopsis: The easiest way to create a [[GPS Path]] is to use a mobile phone and software that logs your location. The paths can then be linked together from the log of the GPS points to create a smooth path.

title: Maps
synopsis: Here we look at how to work with maps in wiki. In particular we want to look out how we can use wiki to create and document walks, oral histories, and map festivals.

title: Maps and Places
synopsis: We've begun some work on the long neglected map plugin. Here we consider how maps might interact with the rest of the lineup, neighborhood and federation.

title: Maps and things
synopsis: Below are a collection of links imported from [[OneTab]]. You can view these links here - [https://www.one-tab.com/page/LBuWYOdXSheZW5mMvt7yew one-tab.com]:

title: OpenStreetMap
synopsis: OpenStreetMap (OSM) is a collaborative project to create a free editable map of the world - [http://www.openstreetmap.org openstreetmap.org]

title: Outlandish Activity
synopsis: View all activity of the [[Outlandish Researchers]]  listed in the roster below, writing across education initiatives in the [[Outlandish Academy]]:

title: Place
synopsis: Our notion of place is not simply physical, we are able or rather need to identify with it in many ways.

title: Ushahidi
synopsis: Ushahidi, Inc. is a non-profit software company that develops free and open-source software (LGPL) for information collection, visualisation, and interactive mapping.

title: Welcome Visitors
synopsis: On this site we research [[Place]]s and [[Maps]] for the [[Outlandish Academy]]. In particular we look at mapping spaces, walks, and conversations, together with the software that enables this.
